fields.name: action
fields.comment: The action taken by the network device.

fields.name: app
fields.comment: The application protocol of the traffic.

fields.name: bytes
fields.comment: Total count of bytes handled by this device/interface (bytes_in + bytes_out).

fields.name: bytes_in
fields.comment: How many bytes this device/interface received.

fields.name: bytes_out
fields.comment: How many bytes this device/interface transmitted.

fields.name: channel
fields.comment: The 802.11 channel used by a wireless network.

fields.name: dest
fields.comment: The destination of the network traffic (the remote host). You can alias this from more specific fields, such as dest_host, dest_ip, or dest_name.

fields.name: dest_interface
fields.comment: The interface that is listening remotely or receiving packets locally. Can also be referred to as the 'egress interface.'

fields.name: dest_ip
fields.comment: The IP address of the destination.

fields.name: dest_mac
fields.comment: The destination TCP/IP layer 2 Media Access Control (MAC) address of a packet's destination, such as 06:10:9f:eb:8f:14. Note: Always force lower case on this field and use colons instead of dashes, spaces, or no separator.

fields.name: dest_port
fields.comment: The destination port of the network traffic. Note: Do not translate the value of this field to a string (tcp/80 is 80, not http). You can set up the corresponding string value in the dest_svc field.

fields.name: dest_translated_ip
fields.comment: The NATed IPv4 or IPv6 address to which a packet has been sent.

fields.name: dest_translated_port
fields.comment: The NATed port to which a packet has been sent. Note: Do not translate the values of this field to strings (tcp/80 is 80, not http).

fields.name: dest_zone
fields.comment: The network zone of the destination.

fields.name: direction
fields.comment: The direction the packet is traveling.

fields.name: duration
fields.comment: The amount of time for the completion of the network event, in seconds.

fields.name: dvc
fields.comment: The device that reported the traffic event. You can alias this from more specific fields, such as dvc_host, dvc_ip, or dvc_name.

fields.name: dvc_mac
fields.comment: The device TCP/IP layer 2 Media Access Control (MAC) address of a packet's destination, such as 06:10:9f:eb:8f:14. Note: Always force lower case on this field and use colons instead of dashes, spaces, or no separator.

fields.name: dvc_zone
fields.comment: The network zone of the device.

fields.name: flow_id
fields.comment: Unique identifier for this traffic stream, such as a netflow, jflow, or cflow.

fields.name: icmp_code
fields.comment: The RFC 2780 or RFC 4443 human-readable code value of the traffic, such as Destination Unreachable or Parameter Problem . See the ICMP Type Numbers and the ICMPv6 Type Numbers.

fields.name: icmp_type
fields.comment: The RFC 2780 or RFC 4443 numeric value of the traffic. See the ICMP Type Numbers and the ICMPv6 Type Numbers.

fields.name: packets
fields.comment: The total count of packets handled by this device/interface (packets_in + packets_out).

fields.name: packets_in
fields.comment: The total count of packets received by this device/interface.

fields.name: packets_out
fields.comment: The total count of packets transmitted by this device/interface.

fields.name: protocol
fields.comment: The OSI layer 3 (network) protocol of the traffic observed, in lower case. For example, ip, appletalk, ipx.

fields.name: protocol_version
fields.comment: Version of the OSI layer 3 protocol.

fields.name: response_time
fields.comment: The amount of time it took to receive a response in the network event, in seconds.

fields.name: rule
fields.comment: The rule which defines the action that was taken in the network event. Note: This is a string value. Use rule_id for rule fields that are integer data types. The rule_id field is optional, so it is not included in the data model

fields.name: session_id
fields.comment: The session identifier. Multiple transactions build a session.

fields.name: src
fields.comment: The source of the network traffic (the client requesting the connection). You can alias this from more specific fields, such as src_host, src_ip, or src_name.'

fields.name: src_interface
fields.comment: The interface that is listening locally or sending packets remotely. Can also be referred to as the 'ingress interface.'

fields.name: src_translated_ip
fields.comment: The interface that is listening locally or sending packets remotely. Can also be referred to as the 'ingress interface.'

fields.name: src_zone
fields.comment: The network zone of the source.

fields.name: ssid
fields.comment: The 802.11 service set identifier (ssid) assigned to a wireless session.

fields.name: wifi
fields.comment: The wireless standard(s) in use, such as 802.11a, 802.11b, 802.11g, or 802.11n.

fields.name: tcp_flag
fields.comment: The TCP flag or multiple flags specified in the event.

fields.name: tos
fields.comment: The combination of source and destination IP ToS (type of service) values in the event.

fields.name: ttl
fields.comment: The 'time to live' of a packet or diagram, in seconds.

fields.name: user
fields.comment: The user that requested the traffic flow.

fields.name: vendor_product
fields.comment: The vendor and product of the device generating the network event. This field can be automatically populated by vendor and product fields in your data.

fields.name: vlan
fields.comment: The virtual local area network (VLAN) specified in the record.

fields.name: transport
fields.comment: The OSI layer 4 (transport) protocol of the traffic observed, in lower case.

fields.name: src_ip
fields.comment: The ip address of the source.

fields.name: src_mac
fields.comment: The source TCP/IP layer 2 Media Access Control (MAC) address of a packet's destination, such as 06:10:9f:eb:8f:14. Note: Always force lower case on this field and use colons instead of dashes, spaces, or no separator.

fields.name: src_port
fields.comment: The source port of the network traffic. Note: Do not translate the value of this field to a string (tcp/80 is 80, not http). You can set up the corresponding string value in the src_svc field.

fields.name: src_translated_port
fields.comment: The NATed port from which a packet has been sent. Note: Do not translate the values of this field to strings (tcp/80 is 80, not http.
